Award.AwardTitle: Learning to Attend, Attending to Learn: Neurological, Behavioral, and Computational Perspectives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Attention and learning are two of the most important aspects of cognition. While studying attention and learning separately has its benefits, it is also misleading. In the past few years, there has emerged a new wave of research demonstrating that attention constrains learning and that learning guides future attention. The studies in these two areas span disparate fields (developmental psychology, cognitive neuroscience, behavioral neuroscience, computational modeling). Although researchers are asking the same questions across different fields, in general, they do not attend the same conferences, rarely cite each other, and in most cases do not even know about each other's work. This 2-day workshop will bring together these diverse researchers to catalyze further interaction and promote innovative collaborative research. The workshop also will include moderators, who will encourage constructive critiques and discussion of theoretical and methodological limitations for the different approaches.

This workshop will solidify, stabilize, and grow this critical research area (especially for a new generation of researchers) and thereby promote a more nuanced, ecologically valid, and biologically informed understanding of attention-learning interactions and mechanisms. Research on attention and learning interactions is crucial for understanding a wide range of developmental processes, including infants' development of social skills, children's memory, perceptual-motor skill acquisition, and learning in school. It is also increasingly apparent that developmental disabilities originally thought to be attention-based, such as ADHD, interact heavily with learning difficulties, though the exact mechanisms are still unclear.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary: This workshop (Nov 6-7, 2013) bridged sub-disciplines by bringing together top-notch researchers from separate fields (e.g., neuroscience, developmental psychology, and computational modeling) to discuss common questions on attention and learning. The event was an incredible success, with registration selling out in one week and outstanding feedback (4.5/5) from the 26 speakers and discussants and more than 100 participants. The feedback included comments about learning a lot that they did not know before the workshop and forming new collaborations. The entire workshop was professionally filmed (V-CUBE USA, Inc.), and the videos, abstracts, and photos are hosted on the workshop website (www.attention-learning.com). Since early December 2013 after the workshop, the website has received more than 1,600 visits (72% new visitors) from 10 different countries. 

Intellectual Merit: This workshop solidified, stabilized, and fostered this critical research area, especially for a new generation of researchers, to allow for a more ecological understanding of learning mechanisms. Especially during the discussion sessions, this workshop identified major questions, explored complementary approaches, and highlighted the challenges that exist in the different areas to push forward this new avenue of research with feasible collaborations.

Broader Impact: The workshop initiated a sustained enterprise to encourage cross-talk and collaboration on attention and learning interactions. We have begun discussions with interested faculty on the next version of the workshop in a couple of years. The next version of the workshop will address questions of practical importance, namely, (a) Learning-Attention Interactions in Educational Settings; and (b) Diversity of Learning-Attention Interactions: Phenotypes in Developmental Disorders. The workshop was also a unique opportunity promoting, training, and teaching early-career researchers (PhD students and postdocs), as well as those who were involved with the organization. The workshop continues to be useful for early-career researchers given the unrestricted dissemination of the talks via the workshop website.
